H0.text: Chemical composition is the information about stars that can be learned by using a spectrometer.

H1.text: Distance from Earth is the information about stars that can be learned by using a spectrometer.

H2.text: Size is the information about stars that can be learned by using a spectrometer.

H3.text: Speed is the information about stars that can be learned by using a spectrometer.

A4.text: A stellar spectrum can reveal many properties of stars, such as their chemical composition, temperature, density, mass, distance and luminosity.

A5.text: Spectroscopy can show the velocity of motion towards or away from the observer by measuring the Doppler shift.

A6.text: Spectrometers are used in astronomy to analyze the chemical composition of stars and planets

A7.text: Because each element leaves its spectral signature in the pattern of lines observed, a spectral analysis can reveal the composition of the object being analyzed
